entry.name: Active Record
entry.value: The Active Record design pattern is new to many developers but has become familiar due to well recognized and respected implementations including the Ruby on Rails framework. There are many flavors of this design pattern. Most implementations are of one object which represents one row in a database. The object has assessors and mutators (methods for getting and setting values) as well as methods for reading a record, saving it, and deleting it. There are also frequently methods for accessing related objects in the database.

entry.name: Bean
entry.value: A Bean is traditionally a component which encapsulates its instance data in private properties. It then provided “getters and setters” (assessors and mutators, technically) which are used to read and write those values.

entry.name: CRUD
entry.value: CRUD stands for Create, Read, Update and Delete. These are the four actions provided by Data Access Objects.

entry.name: Data Access Object
entry.value: Data Access Objects (commonly called DAOs) are objects which provide methods for creating, reading, updating and deleting a single record in a database. These are generically known as “CRUD” methods.

entry.name: DTD
entry.value: Document Type Definition. A file that describes the structure of an XML document.

entry.name: Table Data Gateway
entry.value: See GatewayTable Data Gateway objects (commonly known as Gateway Objects) are used to interact with multiple rows in a database. Most methods in these objects return record sets (queries) and perform select statements.
